author: Justin Harp
title: Two new X-Men spinoff shows titled Legion and Hellfire are finally coming to FX and Fox - US TV
text: Two new live-action X-Men TV series are finally becoming a reality with Legion and Hellfire.FX is partnering with Agents of SHIELD's Jeph Loeb, X-Men producers Bryan Singer and Simon Kinberg as well as Fargo creator Noah Hawley for the live-action Legion pilot. © Marvel ComicsX-Men character Legion Fans of the X-Men comic books will likely know that Legion is the code name of the vastly powerful mutant psychic David Charles Haller, the son of Professor Charles Xavier and Holocaust survivor Gabrielle Haller.FX describes the series as follows: "Since he was a teenager, David has struggled with mental illness. Diagnosed as schizophrenic, David has been in and out of psychiatric hospitals for years. "But after a strange encounter with a fellow patient, he's confronted with the possibility that the voices he hears and the visions he sees might be real.""Legion is just the sort of ambitious story that Noah excels at," FX programming president Nick Grad said today (October 14)."His adaption of Fargo for television was one of the most acclaimed television events in recent memory. It's also an honour to partner with Marvel on Legion and to enlist such an accomplished team of executive producers to create this pilot." Professor Charles Xavier in X-Men: Days of Future Past No X-Men TV series will ever beat the '90s cartoon and here's whySince Legion's debut in the pages of Marvel Comics all the way back in 1985, the mutant has been a member of the X-Men and its splinter Muir Island faction.A separate Fox series is in development based on classic X-Men villains the Hellfire Club - who played a key role in the iconic 'Dark Phoenix Saga' and were previously featured in the live-action film X-Men: First Class.In the '60s-set Hellfire, a special agent comes into contact with a supernaturally-gifted woman involved in a conspiracy to take control of the world. © Marvel ComicsEmma Frost of the Hellfire Club 24's Evan Katz, Star Trek: Enterprise's Manny Coto and Star Trek 3's Patrick McKay and JD Payne are partnering for Hellfire."We are thrilled to partner with Marvel to bring this world to television and build upon the Fox Logovibrant mythology that has captivated fans for years," Fox Entertainment president David Madden said of Hellfire."These powerful and dynamic characters are complicated and larger-than-life, the pace and visual imagination are unrelenting, and the story takes place during one of the most explosive eras in recent history."Earlier in the year, Fox co-chairmen Dana Walden and Gary Newman confirmed that talks were finally underway for a television show set in the X-Men universe.In terms of the big screen, the franchise's next instalment X-Men: Apocalypse will open in May 2016.
